title: The Economics Of Art And The Art Of Economics
summary:
Key ideas
- There is debate and concern over the possibility of Detroit selling masterpieces from its art museum to solve its temporary financial problem.
- Keeping priceless paintings on display would cost more than $6,000 an hour.
- The cost of keeping "The Wedding Dance" by Pieter Bruegel the Elder on display would be more than $1200 per hour per visitor.
- The author suggests sell every piece of art in Detroit and hire skilled forgers to make exact copies of them for a couple of hundred dollars each.

Key learnings
- Trying to think quantitatively can make the right answer obvious.
- Consequentialism is hard but can help avoid making costly mistakes.
- Skilled forgers can make exact copies of priceless art pieces for a fraction of the cost.

Key questions
- Is solving a temporary financial problem worth sacrificing cultural heritage?
- Does the average visitor to an art museum derive enough value from seeing a particular painting to justify its high cost?
- How can consequentialism help make better decisions even when we can never do it exactly right?
